title: 1731-A
statement: A. Joey Takes Moneytime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputJoey is low on money. His friend Chandler wants to lend Joey some money, but can't give him directly, as Joey is too proud of himself to accept it. So, in order to trick him, Chandler asks Joey to play a game.In this game, Chandler gives Joey an array $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$n \\geq 2$$$) of positive integers ($$$a_i \\ge 1$$$).Joey can perform the following operation on the array any number of times:Take two indices $$$i$$$ and $$$j$$$ ($$$1 \\le i < j \\le n)$$$.Choose twointegers$$$x$$$ and $$$y$$$ ($$$x, y \\ge 1$$$) such that $$$x \\cdot y = a_i \\cdot a_j$$$.Replace $$$a_i$$$ by $$$x$$$ and $$$a_j$$$ by $$$y$$$.In the end, Joey will get the money equal tothe sumof elements of the final array.Find the maximum amount of money $$$\\mathrm{ans}$$$ Joey can getbut print$$$2022 \\cdot \\mathrm{ans}$$$. Why multiplied by $$$2022$$$? Because we are never gonna see it again!It is guaranteed that the product of all the elements of the array $$$a$$$ doesn't exceed $$$10^{12}$$$.InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 4000$$$). Description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\leq n \\leq 50$$$) — the length of the array $$$a$$$.The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq a_i \\leq 10^6$$$) — the array itself.It's guaranteed that the product of all $$$a_i$$$ doesn't exceed $$$10^{12}$$$ (i. e. $$$a_1 \\cdot a_2 \\cdot \\ldots \\cdot a_n \\le 10^{12}$$$).OutputFor each test case, print the maximum money Joey can getmultiplied by$$$2022$$$.ExampleInput332 3 221 331000000 1000000 1Output28308 8088 2022000000004044NoteIn the first test case, Joey can do the following:He chooses $$$i = 1$$$ and $$$j = 2$$$ (so he has $$$a[i] \\cdot a[j] = 6$$$), chooses $$$x = 6$$$ and $$$y = 1$$$ and makes $$$a[i] = 6$$$ and $$$a[j] = 1$$$. $$$$$$[2, 3, 2] \\xrightarrow[x = 6,\\; y = 1]{i = 1,\\; j = 2} [6, 1, 2]$$$$$$He chooses $$$i = 1$$$ and $$$j = 3$$$ (so he has $$$a[i] \\cdot a[j] = 12$$$), chooses $$$x = 12$$$ and $$$y = 1$$$ and makes $$$a[i] = 12$$$ and $$$a[j] = 1$$$. $$$$$$[6, 1, 2] \\xrightarrow[x = 12,\\; y = 1]{i = 1,\\; j = 3} [12, 1, 1]$$$$$$The sum is $$$14$$$ which is the maximum of all possible sums. The answer is $$$2022 \\cdot 14 = 28308$$$.

You are given an array of positive integers $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$. You can perform the following operation any number of times:

1. Choose two indices $i$ and $j$ where $1 \le i < j \le n$.
2. Choose two integers $x$ and $y$ where $x, y \ge 1$ such that $x \cdot y = a_i \cdot a_j$.
3. Replace $a_i$ with $x$ and $a_j$ with $y$.

Find the maximum sum of the elements in the array after performing these operations. Multiply the maximum sum by 2022 and output the result. 

The product of all elements in the array does not exceed $10^{12}$.

You are given a list of positive integers. You can repeatedly choose two numbers from the list and split their product into two new numbers, replacing the original numbers in the list.  What is the largest possible sum of the numbers in the list you can achieve?
